H0.text: Testing five kittens on a non‑meat diet also would have made Raquel’s experiment better by providing a comparison group to her all‑meat diet, allowing her to determine whether eating meat is truly the best way to help kittens grow.

H1.text: Weighed the kittens in grams should have been done by Raquel to improve the experiment in which she fed a litter of five kittens an all‑meat diet for two weeks, recorded an average gain of 15 ounces, and concluded that eating meat is the best way to help kittens grow.

H2.text: Using only one kitten would have made Raquel’s experiment better, as she had fed a litter of five kittens an all‑meat diet for two weeks, observed an average gain of 15 ounces, and concluded that eating meat is the best way to help kittens grow.

H3.text: Testing dogs as well as cats would have made Raquel’s experiment better by providing a control group and allowing comparison of growth between species after the two‑week all‑meat diet that caused the five kittens to gain an average of 15 ounces and led her to conclude that eating meat is the best way to help kittens grow.

A4.text: In some experiments, such as many in agriculture or psychology, this can be achieved by randomly assigning items from a common population to one of the treatment and control groups.

A5.text: In some medical studies, where it may be unethical not to treat patients who present with symptoms, controls may be given a standard treatment, rather than no treatment at all.
